rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 115: Line 115:
[[File:Pervez Musharraf - World Economic Forum Annual Meeting Davos 2008 number3.jpg|thumb|left|former Pakistan [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Pervez Musharraf]]]]
[[File:Pervez Musharraf - World Economic Forum Annual Meeting Davos 2008 number3.jpg|thumb|left|former Pakistan [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Pervez Musharraf]]]]
'''[[General]]''' '''[[Pervez Musharraf]]''' (Ù¾Ø±ÙÛØ² ÙØ´Ø±Ù) (born 11 August 1943), a [[Four star rank|4 star]] [[Four star general|general]] at that time was [[Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee (Pakistan)|Chairman]] of [[Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee, Pakistan|Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee]] (1998â2001) and the [[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Army Staff]] of the Pakistan Army (1998â2007). In 2001, he would go on to become Pakistan's military ruler and president. Pervez Musharraf - then as Chief of Army Staff - was responsible for sending thousands of Pakistani nationals to fight alongside the Taliban and Bin Laden against [[Ahmad Shah Massoud]].<ref name="National Geographic"/><ref name="History Commons"/><ref name="George Washington University">{{cite web |year=2007 |url =http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB227/index.htm#17 |title =Documents Detail Years of Pakistani Support for Taliban, Extremists | publisher = [[George Washington University]]}}</ref> In total there were believed to be 28,000 Pakistani nationals fighting inside Afghanistan against the forces of Massoud.<ref name="Webster University Press Book"/> 20,000 were regular Pakistani soldiers either from the [[Frontier Corps]], 50th Airborne Division or 12th regular army regiments, and an estimated 8,000 were militants recruited in [[madrassa]]s filling regular Taliban ranks.<ref name="Ahmed Rashid/The Telegraph">{{cite web|year=2001|url =http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/afghanistan/1340244/Afghanistan-resistance-leader-feared-dead-in-blast.html |title =Afghanistan resistance leader feared dead in blast| publisher = Ahmed Rashid in the Telegraph}}</ref> The estimated 25,000 Taliban regular force thus comprised more than 8,000 Pakistani nationals.<ref name="Ahmed Rashid/The Telegraph">{{cite web|year=2001|url =http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/afghanistan/1340244/Afghanistan-resistance-leader-feared-dead-in-blast.html |title =Afghanistan resistance leader feared dead in blast| publisher = Ahmed Rashid in the Telegraph}}</ref> A 1998 document by the [[U.S. State Department]] confirms that "20-40 percent of [regular] Taliban soldiers are Pakistani."<ref name="George Washington University"/> The document further states that the parents of those Pakistani nationals "know nothing regarding their child's military involvement with the Taliban until their bodies are brought back to Pakistan."<ref name="George Washington University"/> A further 3,000 fighter of the regular Taliban army were Arab and Central Asian militants.<ref name="Ahmed Rashid/The Telegraph">{{cite web|year=2001|url =http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/afghanistan/1340244/Afghanistan-resistance-leader-feared-dead-in-blast.html |title =Afghanistan resistance leader feared dead in blast| publisher = Ahmed Rashid in the Telegraph}}</ref> Of roughly 45,000 Pakistani, Taliban and Al Qaeda soldiers fighting against the forces of Massoud only 14,000 were Afghan (Taliban).<ref name="Ahmed Rashid/The Telegraph">{{cite web|year=2001|url =http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/afghanistan/1340244/Afghanistan-resistance-leader-feared-dead-in-blast.html |title =Afghanistan resistance leader feared dead in blast| publisher = Ahmed Rashid in the Telegraph}}</ref><ref name="Webster University Press Book"/>
'''[[General]]''' '''[[Pervez Musharraf]]''' (Ù¾Ø±ÙÛØ² ÙØ´Ø±Ù) (born 11 August 1943), a [[Four star rank|4 star]] [[Four star general|general]] at that time was [[Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee (Pakistan)|Chairman]] of [[Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee, Pakistan|Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee]] (1998â2001) and the [[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Army Staff]] of the Pakistan Army (1998â2007). to Pakistan."<ref name="George Washington University"/> A further 3,000 fighter of the regular Taliban army were Arab and Central Asian militants.<ref name="Ahmed Rashid/The Telegraph">{{cite blast| publisher = Ahmed Rashid in the Telegraph}}</ref> Of roughly 45,000 Pakistani, Taliban and Al Qaeda soldiers fighting against the forces of Massoud only 14,000 were Afghan (Taliban).<ref name="Ahmed Rashid/The Telegraph">{{cite web|year=2001|url =http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/afghanistan/1340244/Afghanistan-resistance-leader-feared-dead-in-blast.html |title =Afghanistan resistance leader feared dead in blast| publisher = Ahmed Rashid in the Telegraph}}</ref><ref name="Webster University Press Book"/>
â
[[File:Gen.Mahmud Ahmed.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Lieutenant General Mahmood Ahmad (far right), [[Pakistan Army|PA]].]]
 
'''[[Lieutenant-General]] [[Mahmud Ahmed]]''' - Lieutenant General Ahmad, as [[Three star rank|3 star]] rank [[3 star general|general]] along with other generals was successful in overthrowing the elected Pakistani democratic government of Prime minister [[Nawaz Sharif]] in a 1999 coup d'Ã©tat to bring General Pervez Musharraf to political power in Islamabad. Lieutenant-General Mahmud Ahmed himself became director general of the Pakistani Inter-Services Intelligence after the coup. The ISI was responsible for the support to the Taliban. Many of its officers, such as [[Lieutenant-General]] [[Hamid Gul]], Lieutenant-General Naseem Rana, Lieutenant-General [[Ziauddin Butt]] and retired [[Colonel]] [[Colonel Imam|Sultan Amir Tarar]], played a major role in the war. The officers provided financial, economic, strategic, and military assistance to the Taliban.
'''[[Lieutenant-General]] [[Mahmud Ahmed]]''' - Lieutenant General Ahmad, as [[Three star rank|3 star]] rank [[3 star general|general]] along with other generals was successful in overthrowing the elected Pakistani democratic government of Prime minister [[Nawaz Sharif]] in a 1999 coup d'Ã©tat to bring General Pervez Musharraf to political power in Islamabad. Lieutenant-General Mahmud Ahmed himself became director general of the Pakistani Inter-Services Intelligence after the coup. The ISI was responsible for the support to the Taliban. Many of its officers, such as [[Lieutenant-General]] [[Hamid Gul]], Lieutenant-General Naseem Rana, Lieutenant-General [[Ziauddin Butt]] and retired [[Colonel]] [[Colonel Imam|Sultan Amir Tarar]], played a major role in the war. The officers provided financial, economic, strategic, and military assistance to the Taliban.
